key_insight: Neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion can accurately generate single-cell trajectories and simulate perturbations, outperforming prior deterministic or fixed-noise models.
problem_solved: How to model and generate realistic, stochastic cell-state dynamics from single-cell data — including state-dependent variability — and enable in silico perturbation studies for development and disease.
method: Parameterize both drift and diffusion functions with neural networks to form a neural stochastic differential equation (SDE) generative model.
Train the model on single-cell time-resolved or pseudotime data to capture state-dependent dynamics and uncertainty, then sample trajectories via SDE solvers.
Use the learned model to simulate interventions/perturbations and compare predicted developmental or disease trajectories against baselines.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a principled, generative approach to capture stochastic, state-dependent dynamics with uncertainty estimates, useful for interpretable simulations, perturbation testing, and bridging mechanistic and data-driven models in biology.
visual_elements: Schematic of the model: neural nets → learned drift & diffusion → SDE solver → generated cell trajectories
Comparative trajectory plot: ground-truth single-cell measurements vs. model samples vs. baseline methods
Heatmap or vector field showing state-dependent diffusion and drift across cell-state space
Before/after perturbation panel illustrating predicted trajectory shifts under simulated interventions
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
